choices.text: Patient's pain is likely to be relieved by Salicylates
CT is the best investigation to see pathological lesion
It is most common True Benign Bone Tumour

questions.text: A 18 yr old boy presented with pain in his thigh region without H/O any significant injury. His X Rays revealed a Lytic lesion in Diaphysis surrounded by sclerosis. All of the following statements regarding his clinical condition are likely to be true except:-
questions.solution:
Above Clinical history and ct image suggests diagnosis of osteoid osteoma

Osteoid osteoma:-

  • benign bone forming lesion considered to be the most common true benign tumor of the bone
  • Age group:- 2nd -3rd decades
  • Male:female 3:1
  • Lower extremity,long bones,Posterior elements spine ,Diaphyseal/metaphyseal
  • CT is the modality of choice and typically shows a focally lucent nidus within surrounding sclerotic reactive bone. A central sclerotic dot may also be seen.
  • Pain; worse at night
  • XRAY:-Cortical radiolucent nidus <1.5 cm with marked cortical thickening
  • High levels of cyclooxygenases and prostaglandins in the lesion
  • Frequently responds to NSAIDs
  • HISTOLOGY:-Trabeculae surrounded by loose fibrovascular tissue
  • TREATMENT:-NSAIDs, Burr down technique ,Radiofrequency ablation.

Ref.maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 236

choices.text: Derived from Monocytes and are multinucleated giant cells
Have enzymes like TRAP and Carbonic Anhydrase

questions.text: True about Osteoclasts are all except:
questions.solution:
Osteoclast: these are bone reabsorbing multinucleated giant cells derived from mononuclear precursors of macrophage lineage (specifically monocytes) in the marrow. these cells are activated by osteoblast. their main function is to resorb bone and is thus involved in bone remodeling. Active osteoclasts are present in excavations in bone formed by them after erosion of matrix, the excavations being called as 'Howship's lacunae'

Ref.fundamentals of orthopedics mohindra and jain 1st edition page no 7

choices.text: M/C site is Middle and Lateral Thirds
It is the M/C Bone fracture in adults
Usually treated by Figure of Eight Bandage

questions.text: All are true regarding Clavicle Fracture except:
questions.solution:
Malunion is the most common complication

the first bone to ossify in the human skeleton is the clavicle.

It is only long bone to ossify by intramembranous ossification. It ossifies at 5th week of intrauterine life and that is when the human skeleton starts forming.

Clavicle is also the last bone to complete ossification. Mandible is the second bone to ossify after clavicle by intra-membranous ossification.

Clavicle is the most common bone to be fractured at birth followed by humerus

An undisplaced fracture of lateral end of the clavicle may be managed only with a broad arm sling A figure-of-8 bandage may be applied to a young adult with a displaced fracture

Malunion is the most common complication and may result in formation of an undue prominence that is a relative indication for surgery in patients having problem with cosmesis

Ref.maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no88.

choices.text: Non-Union leads to Cubitus Varus Deformity

questions.text: All of the following statements are false regarding Supracondylar Fracture Humerus except:
questions.solution:
Three bony points relationship: The three prominent bony points around the elbow i.e., the medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle and tip of the olecranon are important landmarks in the diagnosis of injuries around the elbow.

Normally, in an elbow flexed to 90°, these three bony points form a near-isosceles triangle, but they lie in a straight horizontal line in an extended elbow



In Supracondylar humerus fracture three bony point relationships is maintained as such in normal elbow because fracture line runs above the condyles

Ref maheshwari ortho 4th edition page no 96.

choices.text: Immediate X Ray followed by POP application
Blood tests to rule out Acute Osteomyelitis

questions.text: one and a half year old child holding her father's hand suddenly slipped and fell but did not let go her father's hand. Immediately after the injury she started crying. At the time of presentation to the hospital, the Orthopaedician on call noticed decreased movements of the affected Elbow joint with forearm in an attitude of Pronation. What is the most appropriate management:
questions.solution:
Above clinical scenario favours diagnosis of pulled elbow( NURSEMAID ELBOW)

In young children the elbow is sometimes injured by a sharp tug on the wrist.

The child is in pain; The child keeps his elbow flexed with forearm in pronation and he or she will not allow it to be moved.

There are no x-ray changes.

What has happened is that the radius has been pulled distally and the annular ligament has slipped up over the head of the radius.

A dramatic cure is achieved by forcefully supinating and then flexing the elbow; the ligament slips back with a snap. click may be felt in child's elbow while reducing it. The child stops crying and starts using his limb within minutes after reduction

Ref-maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no-105

choices.text: M/C Displacements are Dorsal and Lateral
M/C complication is Malunion producing a Dinner Fork Deformity
Commonly seen in Elderly Osteoporotic patients

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Colle's Fracture except:
questions.solution:
Finger stiffness is the commonest complication; the shoulder, wrist and elbow are the other joints which commonly get stiff

Colles fractures are very common extra-articular fractures of the distal radius that occur as the result of a fall onto an outstretched hand. They consist of a fracture of the distal radial metaphyseal region with dorsal angulation and impaction, but without the involvement of the articular surface.

They are particularly common in patients with osteoporosis, and as such, they are most frequently seen in elderly women.

Mechanism:-Most Colles fractures are secondary to a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) with a pronated forearm in wrist extension.

Dinner fork deformity can be seen if enough dorsal angulation is present.

Garden spade deformity is seen in volar angulation type fracture (smith fracture)

Gunstock deformity is seen in malunited Supracondylar humerus fracture.

Ref Fundamentals of orthopedics Mahindra 1st edition page no 70

questions.text: Mirel's criteria is developed for the evaluation of
questions.solution:
Risk of pathological fracture Mirels Criteria For Risk of Pathological Fracture:

  • Mirel's developed a scoring system based on, the presence or absence of pain,the size, location, and radiographic appearance of the lesion to quantify the risk of impending pathological fracture in malignant lesion.
  • So patients with maximum risk of pathological fracture are having lytic peritrochanteric lesion involving >2/3 diameter with severe pain
  • Patients with < 7 score are observed, but those with 8 or more should have prophylactic internal fixation.

Ref.fundamentals of orthopedics 1st edition page no 37

choices.text: Upper ulner fracture & disloated radial head

questions.text: True regarding Monteggia fracture is:
questions.solution:
MONTEGGIA FRACTURE-This is a fracture of the upper-third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. It is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation consist of fracture of the distal part of the radius with dislocation of distal radioulnar joint and an intact ulna.

bowing fracture: the bone is bowed, but there is no discernible fracture

Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures of long bones and are usually seen in young children, more commonly less than 10 years of age. They are commonly mid-diaphyseal, affecting the forearm and lower leg.


Ref. Apleys orthopedics 9th edition 770page no.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in Crush Syndrome Except:
questions.solution:
Metabolic derangements include hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia and hyponatremia. With shifting of intravascular fluid into cells, patients frequently develop shock.

CRUSH SYNDROME This syndrome results from massive crushing of the muscles, commonly associated with crush injuries sustained during earthquakes, air raids, mining and other such accidents.

Crushing of muscles results in entry of myohaemoglobin into the circulation, which precipitates in renal tubules, leading to acute renal tubular necrosis.

Treatment: It is largely supportive. Restoration of circulating blood volume to normalize urine output and normalization of metabolic derangements are the main goals of treatment. Up to one-third of patients develop acute renal failure and require dialysis.

Ref-maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no-44

questions.text: An army recruit, smoker and 6 months into training started complaining of pain at Postero medial aspect of both legs. There was acute point tenderness and the pain was aggravated by physical activity. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Stress Fracture: This is a special type of fracture sustained due to chronic repetitive injury (stress) causing a break in bony trabeculae. These often present as only pain and may not be visible on X-rays.

Tibia is the most common site of stress fracture (proximal or distal thirds).

  • Navicular is the most common tarsal bone to sustain stress fracture. Shaft of metatarsals are most common site of stress fracture in foot.
  • Use of running shoes, shock absorber inserts in shoes and modi!cation of running mechanics (increase in cadence and decrease in stride length) are simple measures to prevent lower limb stress fractures.

Best diagnostic test for unilateral stress fracture is MRI, and for bilateral is bone scan

March: stress fracture of shaft of 2nd metatarsal

Activity modi!cation is enough for most of the stress fractures. For stress fractures of foot bones (metatarsals, navicular), nonweight bearing below knee cast immobilization for 4-6 weeks is the treatment of choice

Ref-maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no-2

choices.text: Lateral condyle humerus is open reduced
Forearm fracture in children is closed reduced and cast applied
Neck femur fracture in geriatrics is treated with open reduction and screw fixation.

questions.text: All the following are True except: -
questions.solution:
Neck femur fracture in geriatrics is treated with open reduction and screw fixation.

  • Extra articular fracture are closely reduced and intraarticular fractures are treated by open reduction. Supracondylar fracture humerus is extra articular and lateral condyle fracture is intra articular.
  • Neck femur in geriatrics is usually treated by hemiarthroplasty.

Ref-maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no-338

questions.text: A 60 yrs. Female presented to the hospital with a H/O slip at home followed by c/o Pain in Right Hip with difficulty in ambulation. X Rays taken were inconclusive. The next best investigation is:
questions.solution:
Here xray is inconclusive so next best investigation is MRI to rule out hidden stress fracture.

Ref-maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no-7.

choices.text: Indication of Steroid use is meningitis
Dorsal Spine is Most common site affected
Fibrous Ankylosis is most common sequelae of Tubercular Spondylitis

questions.text: All are true about Tuberculosis of Spine (Pott's Spine) except:
questions.solution:
sequelae of potts spine:- Even though infection may be eliminated by chemotherapy, when several vertebrae have been damaged and disk space destroyed, the adjacent vertebrae undergo fusion resulting in bony ankylosis/bone block formation. this is in contrast to other joints where TB leads to "fibrous ankylosis, as in spine the area of contact between cancellous vertebral surfaces is high and in addition weight bearing induces bone formation.

Ref.fundamentals of ortho by mohindra n jain 1st edition page no 245.

questions.text: All of the following are metaphyseal tumors except:
questions.solution:
Chondrblastoma is epiphyseal tumor

Tumors according to their Origin Site in long bone




Ref: Apley's System of Orthopaedics, 9th ed. pg. 198

questions.text: Diagnosis of a patient with the following x ray of wrist is:
questions.solution:
• Widened physis (growth plate)/Cupped and frayed metaphysis are seen here so diagnosis is Rickets
  • Epipyseal dysgenesis/Fragmented/punctate epiphysis are seen in Hypothyroidism
  • Small epiphysis marginated by sclerotic rim (wimberger sign) and calcified rdiodense mataphyseal end (Frankel's line) is seen in scurvy
  • Hyperparathyroidism causes bone resorption.

Ref-maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no-310.

questions.text: True about Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis is ?
questions.solution:
Trethowan sign is seen SCFE is seen in adolescents,seen in obese overweight individuals and seen as a result of minor trauma.Trethowan sign is seen.

Normally, a line drawn along the superior border of neck (Klein's line), should intersect some part of epiphysis (head). But is SCFE, this line intersects a very small part of epiphysis or not at all



(Trethowan sign)

Ref.maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 324

questions.text: Most common muscle damaged in Rotator Cuff:
questions.solution:
The supraspinatus muscle is the most frequently injured rotator cuff muscle. Patients often report pain anteriorly and superiorly to the glenohumeral joint during abduction. The primary motion of the supraspinatus is the first 15 degrees of abduction of the arm, at which point the deltoid muscle continues the motion of abduction the forgotten muscle of the rotator cuff is the subscapularis

ref.fundamentals of orthopedics 1st edition page no 377.

questions.text: A young patient presented to emergency with H/O injury to his Right Shoulder with the affected side in an attitude of Abduction and External Rotation. On Examination, he had weakness of his Elbow flexion and Lack of sensations over the lateral aspect of Forearm. The peripheral nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
MUSCULOCUTANEOUS NERVE PALSY (C5-6) ;- the nerve is a branch of lateral cord of brachial plexus. It is mostly injured by penetrating injuries but seldom in anterior dislocation of the shoulder or fracture of humerus neck. The nerve supplies coracobrachialis (vestigial), brachialis and biceps brachii. This nerve palsy is generally overlooked as it hardly causes any problems. Sensory loss is ill-defined and even though biceps and brachialis are paralyzed, elbow can still be flexed by a strong brachioradialis.

ref.fundamentals of orthopedics 1st edition page no 211.

choices.text: Entrapment of Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of Thigh
Entrapment of Femoral Nerve under Inguinal Ligament

questions.text: A middle aged gentleman presented to Orthopaedic OPD with complaints of Pain and Paresthesia over the anterolateral aspect of thigh. On examination his motor power and Deep tendon reflexes in lower limbs were normal. What is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
MERALGIA PARAESTHETICA This is a feeling of tingling, burning, and numbness in the skin supplied by the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh as it gets entrapped in the fascia just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. Treatment is non-specific with analgesics, local hydrocortisone etc. Sometimes, surgical decompression of the nerve may be required.

Ref.maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 305.

questions.text: Clinical Test for diagnosing rupture of Medial collateral ligament is:
questions.solution:
Medial and lateral collateral ligaments test:- With the patient lying supine, the leg is lifted and held in the axilla. The knee is kept in 20o to 30o of flexion*. Gentle adduction (to test LCL) and abduction (to test MCL) force is applied, as if one is trying to 'force open' the joint on one or the other side. The fingers over the joint line can appreciate 'opening-up' of the joint. Even if the joint does not open up but an attempt to do so produces pain at the ligament, it indicates a partial tear of the ligament being tested.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 356.

questions.text: The characteristic triad of Klippel - Feil syndrome includes all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
This is characterized by congenital fusion of the cervical spine due to failure of segmentation. There is failure of normal division of cervical somites. It may even involve the craniocervical junction (occiput-C1-C2).

Clinical Features Classical triad consists of short-webbed neck, low posterior hair line and restriction of neck movements. Torticollis is present. Scoliosis (congenital or idiopathic) occurs in 60% of patients. Sprengel deformity of shoulder accompanies the syndrome in 50% cases.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 224.

questions.text: Siffert - katz sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Blounts disease In infantile form of Blount's disease varus deformity is usually accompanied by medial tibial torsion, a limp or waggling gait and posteromedial subluxation of knee when held in partial flexion (Siffert-katz sign)

Siffert Katz sign: In Blount's disease, the medial tibial plateau is deformed due to abnormal growth plate.

The medial femoral condyle subluxates posteromedially into the depressed medial tibial plateau at 10-20 degrees of knee flexion. This is called the Siffert katz sign.

Reference fundamentals of orthopedics 1st edition page no 288

questions.text: A patient sustained injury to the upper limb 6 yrs back: he now presents with valgus deformity of the elbow and paresthesias over the medial border of the hand. The injury is likely to have been:
questions.solution:
Child is presented with tardy ulnar nerve palsy symptoms.

Fracture lateral condyle humerus can produce cubitus valgus deformity and tardy ulnar nerve palsy as a late complication.it causes tingling and numbness in ulnar nerve distribution area.

Diminished growth at the lateral side of distal humerus epiphysis results in a cubitus valgus deformity

This may result in late ulnar nerve palsy (tardy ulnar nerve palsy) because of friction neuritis of the ulnar nerve as it moves over the medial epicondyle, everytime the elbow is flexed and extended.

Treatment-anterior transposition of ulnar nerve

Reference- apley's 9th edition page no 371

questions.text: Identify cervical spine injury pattern as per marked arrow:
questions.solution:
Clay Shoveller's fracture: Avulsion fracture of spinous process of vertebrae (C7 > T1)

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 273.

questions.text: Identify the bony pathology in x ray image given below:
questions.solution:
Xray image is showing avascular necrosis of lunate bone which is known as kienbock's disease.

It is osteochondritis of lunate that occurs possible due to a chronic stress injury

MRI is useful in diagnosis and staging and should be considered, after conventional radiography, for patients with suspected Kienbock disease.

There is no single cause of Kienbock's disease. It can be caused by multiple factors such as:

  • Skeletal variations: The ulna bone can be shorter than the radius bone, which may cause issues. Sometimes the shape of the lunate bone may be irregular and place it at risk.
  • Trauma: A single accident or multiple accidents may cause Kienbock's disease.
  • Other medical conditions: Kienbock's disease can be found more commonly in people who have medical conditions that affect blood supply. It is also associated with diseases like lupus, sickle cell anemia and cerebral palsy.

Most patients with Kienbock's disease have the following symptoms:

  • Wrist pain
  • Tenderness directly over the lunate bone
  • Decreased motion or stiffness of the wrist
  • Swelling

Treatment:-

In very early stages, the treatment can be as simple as observation, activity changes, and/or immobilization.

For more advanced stages, surgery is usually considered. Surgery may be done to change forces across the lunate and wrist joint or to improve vascularity of the lunate. When the lunate is severely fracture, collapsed, or arthritic, salvage treatments such as lunate and other wrist bone removal (proximal raw carpectomy) may be necessary.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 318

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
This patients radiograph, and biopsy are consistent with Ewing's sarcoma. Specifically the radiograph shows an infiltrative, non-geographic lesion with periosteal reaction and 'ONION-PEEL APPEARANCE.'

The pathology slide shows a diffuse sheet of small round blue cells lining the bone trabeculae-diagnostic of Ewing's sarcoma.

Current treatment for Ewing's sarcoma include neoadjuvant chemotherapy, surgical resection, and adjuvant chemotherapy. Only in 'unresectable' tumors, or situations where resection would be associated with poor functional outcome would Ewing's be treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy without surgical excision.

Ewing sarcoma is the most chemo-sensitive and most radiosensitive malignant bone tumor.

Ewing sarcoma (> osteosarcoma) is the most common tumor showing bone to bone metastasis, hence mandating a bone scan to detect the metastasis.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 243.

questions.text: Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
This is a benign bone lesion occurring in wide age group, and affects almost any bone. It consists of a blood-filled space enclosed in a shell, ballooning up the overlying cortex - hence its name.

Diagnosis: It is common between 10-40 years of age. Common sites are the long bones, usually at their ends. A gradually increasing swelling is the predominant presentation. There is little pain. Often it presents with a pathological fracture.

Typical radiological fractures are as follows

  • Eccentric well-defined radiolucent area.
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
  • Trabeculation within the substance of the tumour.

Treatment is by curettage and bone grafting. Recurrence occurs in 25 per cent cases. Some surgeons prefer to excise the lesion en bloc and fill the gap with bone grafts.

Reference- maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 249.

questions.text: Most common cause of Non Traumatic Avascular Necrosis:
questions.solution:
Causes of avascular necrosis

  • Idiopathic (most common cause)
  • COAGULATION DISORDER: Familial thrombophilias, hypolipoprotenemia, thrombocytopenic purpura, nephrotic syndrome
  • THROMBOSIS: Hemoglobinopathies (Sickle cell disease), storage disorders (Gaucher's disease), pancreatitis, pregnancy, polycythemia, anticancer drugs, postrenal transplant
  • EMBOLIC OCCLUSION OF VESSELS: Caisson's disease
  • VASCULITIS: Irradiation, SLE (antiphospholipid antibodies)
  • MISCELLENOUS: High-dose steroid therapy, i.e. more than 2 g of prednisone or its equivalent for 2-3 months (occlusion of vessels by fat emboli and increased marrow pressure due to fat accumulation), alcohol intake, HIV, etc

Reference- maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 318.

questions.text: X ray picture shown below is diagnostic of:
questions.solution:
Posterior shoulder dislocations account for only 2-4% of all shoulder dislocations (the vast majority are anterior).

Mechanism:-Typically the humeral head is forced posteriorly in internal rotation while the arm is abducted 1,3. In adults, convulsive disorders are the most common cause. Electrocution is a classic but uncommon cause of posterior shoulder dislocation.

lightbulb sign: fixed internal rotation of the humeral head which takes on a rounded appearance

Anterior dislocation : This is the most common type (90%-95%). Dislocated head lies anteroinferiorly in relation to the glenoid.

Anterior dislocation is further subdivided into following sub-types:-

  • Subcoracoid-It is most common subtype. The head lies inferior to the coracoid process.
  • Subglenoid-Next common sub-type. The head lies on anterior and below the glenoid.
  • Subclavicular-The head lies below the clavicle.
  • Intrathoracic-It is very rare.

Reference maheshwar ortho 5th edition page no 90

questions.text: Pathological triangular area responsible for below mentioned clinical condition is:
questions.solution:
Fairbank's triangle is a sclerotic ossification defect in the inferomedial metaphysis, surrounded by a radiolucent inverted 'Y' of dystrophic bone; when present this is pathognomonic for developmental coxa vara

Reference maheshwar ortho 5th edition page no 323

questions.text: A young female presented in Orthopaedic OPD with Bone pains, Tiredness and easy fatiguability. Her X Rays revealed areas of Radiolucency in region of Pubic Rami: What is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Above clinical history and x ray findings suggests diagnosis of osteomalacia.

CLINICAL FEATURES OF OSTEOMALACIA:-

CLINICAL FEATURES OF OSTEOMALACIA

In its early stages, symptoms and signs are nonspecific and the diagnosis is often missed.

Following presentations may be seen:

  • Bone pains: Skeletal discomfort ranging from backache to diffuse bone pains may occur. Bone tenderness is common.
  • Muscular weakness: The patient feels very weak. He may have difficulty in climbing up and down the stairs. A waddling gait is not unusual.

The characteristic X-ray findings of osteomalacia are Loosers zones named after & mil Looser Swiss surgeon also known as cortical infarctions, Milkman's fractures/pseudofractures that occur due to incomplete healing of stress fractures by a calcium deficient callus. They appear as thin transverse lucencies, running at right angles to the involved cortex since the indentations are caused by vascular crossings pressing on a soft bone. bone margins may be irregular and sclerotic. Often, they are multiple and symmetrical.

Common sites includeLumbar vertebrae pubic and ischial rami, axillary edge of scapula immediately below the glenoid, ribs and clavicle

  • Spontaneous fractures occur usually in spine, and may result in kyphosis.

Radiological examination: Plain X-rays appear to be of 'poor quality' i.e., not sharp and welldefined. Following findings may be present

  • Diffuse rarefaction of bones.
  • Looser's zone (pseudo-fractures): These are radiolucent zones occurring at sites of stress. Common sites are the pubic rami, axillary border of scapula, ribs and the medial cortex of the neck of the femur. These are caused by rapid resorption and slow mineralisation and may be surrounded by a collar of callus.
  • Triradiate pelvis in females.
  • Protrusio-acetabuli i.e., the acetabulum protruding into the pelvis

Reference maheshwar ortho 5th edition page no 312

choices.text: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome Type II
Complex Regional Pain Syndrome Type I

questions.text: A 40 year old Female presented to the clinic after 3 months of traumatic tibial fracture with H/O Pain and swelling of Right Leg since 8-10 days. Her overlying skin was shiny and edematous. There is no associated H/O Hypertension and Diabetes. What is the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Diagnostic Criteria for Complex regional pain syndrome: -

  • Presence of an inciting event
  • Pain disproportionate to this event
  • Presence of signs and symptoms of autonomic imbalance like swelling, edema, vasomotor symptoms trophic changes etc.
  • Exclusion of all other possible causes.
  • Complex regional pain syndrome when associated with nerve damage it is known as CRPS type 2 otherwise it is classified as CRPS type 1.

Reference. fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain 1st edition page no 72

questions.text: A 20 year old boy presented to the emergency with complaints of pain around 1 st Carpo Metacarpal joint after hitting with a closed fist. X Rays revealed an Intra articular fracture of the base of 1st Metacarpal along with subluxation of TrapezioMetacarpal Joint. The fracture pattern described is difficult to maintain in a reduced position mainly because of pull of:
questions.solution:
Bennett's fracture-dislocation: This is is an oblique intra articular fracture of base of first metacarpal, a kind of carpo-metacarpal fracture dislocation in which distal diaphyseal fragment is displaced laterally, proximally and dorsally by combined pull of abductor pollicis longus (primarily ) and adductor pollicis .It is most common of all fractures of base of thumb.

Reference. fundamentals of orthopaedics 1st edition page no 82.

questions.text: Kanavel's sign is positive in:
questions.solution:
The affected finger is grossly swollen and tender.

Kanavel described the four cardinal signs of flexor tenosynovitis:

  1. Fusiform swelling of the finger,
  2. Partially flexed posture of the digit,
  3. Tenderness over the entire flexor tendon sheath and
  4. Disproportionate pain on passive extension. the last sign is the most constant and typically the first being present in early cases.

Reference maheshwar ortho 5th edition page no 209.

questions.text: Identify the bone tumor:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a swelling in mid-thigh region of an 8-year old boy, with femoral thickening with greyish white liquid aspirated from swelling showing atypical round cells with MIC-2 positivity is Ewing's sarcoma.

Ewing's sarcoma: A type of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET) On histopathological examination shows small round cells, which show positive immunohistochemical staining or CD-99 and MIC-2 gene.Although the classical periosteal reaction seen in Ewing's sarcoma is onion peel appearance but sometimes it can present as Codman's triangle.

Ewing's Sarcoma

  • Arises from endothelial cells of the bone marrow in the diaphysis (medullary cavity) of long tubular bones (especially femur) and flat bones of pelvis.
  • Highly malignant, undifferentiated peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET)
  • MC site: Diaphysis of femur >fibula > ilium > tibia.
  • Pathology: Arising in medullary cavity usually invades the cortex, and periosteum producing a soft tissue mass. Composed of sheets of uniform, small round cells (that are slightly larger than lymphocytes), with pale clear appearing cytoplasm due to presence of glycogen.
  • Cytoplasm is PAS positive and diastase digestible.
  • Presence of Homer-Wright rosettes and pseudorosettes is indicative of neural differentiation (i.e. PNET) Express MIC 2 gene in very high amount, distinguish from other round cell tumors
  • Most definitive test: Demonstration of chromosomal translocation by karyotyping or RT PCR DETECTION OF T(11:22)
  • 80%-90% patients have translocation mostly t(11:22)>t(21:22) and rarely t(7:22).
  • Ewing sarcomas are periodic acid Schiff positive (owing to intracellular glycogen) and reticulin negative.

Clinical Feature: - Mostly in males between 10-20 years of age. Pain, swelling, tenderness, urinary/rectal complaints (when ilium involved) pathological fracture. Systemic symptoms such as fever, generalized weakness, weight loss, and lab anomalies as anemia, leukocytosis and raised ESR are hallmark of fulminating courses, advanced disease or metastasis.

50% of all metastases occurs to lung and 25% to bone and bone marrow

Diagnosis: Mottled rarefaction of spongiosa with permeation of overlying cortex, reflecting rapid bone destruction is the principal finding Laminated (layered) periosteal new bone formation known as onion-peel appearance Soft tissue mass, indicating neoplasm has perforated cortex

Treatment: Highly radiosensitive (melts on radiotherapy) but overall survival is not much enhanced Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide Best results are achieved by: Preoperative chemotherapy then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 years. Radiotherapy followed by local excision if it is in less accessible site and then further chemotherapy for 1 year.

Reference maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 243.

questions.text: Spot diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Straddle fracture of the pelvis (fracture of both superior and inferior pubic rami) is considered an unstable injury. The mechanism is a vertical shear injury (in this case a car accident). With straddle fractures, there is a 40% chance of injury to the genitourinary tract.

Reference: maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 124.

questions.text: IDENTIFY FRACTURE
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is a Galeazzi fracture dislocation (reverse Monteggia/Piedmont fracture). There is a fracture of the lower third of radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint. The treatment of choice is open reduction and internal fixation with compression plates.

The counterpart of Galeazzi is Monteggia fracture-dislocation where there is a fracture of the upper third of ulna with dislocation of the radial head.

Both of these fractures are fractures of necessity, i.e., it is necessary to perform open reduction and internal fixation for best results.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 111.

choices.text: Medial meniscus covers less tibial articular surface than Lateral Meniscus
Medial meniscus is less mobile and hence more prone to injury as compared to Lateral Meniscus
Meniscus are Intracapsular and Extrasynovial structures
Medial Meniscus is attached to MCL but Lateral Meniscus is not attached to LCL

questions.text: All the following statements about meniscus are true except:
questions.solution:
MENISCI are intraarticular and intrasynovial structures that derive their nutrition primarily from synovial Fluid.

Each meniscus has a posterior horn, a body and an anterior horn.

Anterior horn is attached in front on the intercondylar tibia and the body courses back along the outer margins of the tibial condyles to insert as the posterior horn on the back of the intercondylar tibia. Also, they are attached to the tibia via the coronary ligaments.

The medial meniscus is larger than the lateral, the latter being more circular while the former is more elliptical.

Reference. fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain 1st edition page no 117.

choices.text: Below Elbow POP Slab in Functional Position

questions.text: A 30 yrs old male involved in a fight, injured his middle finger and noticed a slight flexion of DIP joint. X Rays were normal. The next best management would be:
questions.solution:
Based on clinical findings patient is suffering from mallet finger.

Mallet finger (Baseball finger) results from the sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint so that the extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint is avulsed from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx

Clinically, distal phalanx is in slight flexion. Treatment is by immobilising the DIP joint in hyperextension with the help of an aluminium splint or plaster cast.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 118.

questions.text: In Spondylolisthesis, there is a fracture in which part of Spinal Vertebrae:
questions.solution:
Spondylolisthesis is forward displacement of a vertebra over the one below it. It commonly occurs between L5 -S1, and between L4 -L5. Occasionally, the displacement is backwards (retrolisthesis).

Isthmic: This is the commonest type overall. The lesion is in the pars interarticularis.

Three subtypes are recognised:-

  • Lytic: Fatigue fracture of the pars inter articularis
  • Intact but elongated pars interarticularis
  • Acute fracture of the pars interarticularis.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 284.

choices.text: Injury to the Anterior Interosseus Nerve

questions.text: A patient underwent surgical fixation of Proximal Radius shaft fracture through Posterior (Thompson's approach). Post operatively patient developed inability to extend his Fingers and Thumb. Most likely cause of this will be:
questions.solution:
Supply of posterior interosseous nerve :- the extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) and extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) are primary extensors of the wrist while the extensor indicis (EI) and extensor digitorum communis (EDC) play a prime role in finger extension.

Posterior interosseous nervr supplies these extensor muscles of the forearm.

Posterior interosseous nerve is at risk in proximal radius fracture fixation.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 65.

questions.text: A 5yrd old female child complaints of high grade fever, decreased appetite and pain right hip. On examination he has dehydration/ tenderness in scarpas triangle/swelling in right hip region/absent movements in right hip region. on xray there is mild increase in medial joint space. Diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Septic arthritis Patient is in first 5 years of life with absent movement at joint with toxic presentation goes towards septic arthritis.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 175.

questions.text: Wandering acetabulum is seen in
questions.solution:
• Wandering acetabulum is seen in tuberculosis of hip stage 4 when destroyed head dislocates from the acetabulum

Multiple cavitation is typical of tuberculosis. Such cavities are formed in the femoral head and the acetabulum. Eventually, the head or the acetabulum gets partially absorbed. By the constant pull of the muscles acting on the hip, the remaining head of the femur may dislocate from the acetabulum onto the ilium, giving rise to the so-called wandering acetabulum.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 196.

questions.text:
A known case of Osteoporosis on medications since last 3 years suddenly presented in emergency with pain in thigh with Inability to ambulate. X Rays revealed below.

What is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Long-term use of bisphosphonates drugs (generally over 5 years) has recently caught attention due to special atypical fractures that have been reported in the subtrochanteric area of femur. these are generally transverse insuffciency fractures with thickening of lateral femoral cortex and are associated with slow healing

Reference. fundaments of ortho by mohindra and jain page no 37

questions.text: Initial Focus of TB Hip is:
questions.solution:
Most common site of extraspinal TB is hip. the initial focus starts in acetabular roof (most common), epiphysis, metaphysis (area called as Babecock's triangle) or in greater trochanter

Reference. Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 195.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for below mentioned injury pattern is:
questions.solution:
Best diagnostic test for unilateral stress fracture is MRI, and for bilateral is bone scan:

Reference Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 7.

questions.text: Dupuytren's contracture most often involves
questions.solution:
Dupuytren's contracture involves ring finger>little finger

Most common joint involved is MCP>PIP>DI

Reference. Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 302.

questions.text: A young girl presented with history of trauma 2 months back, now she presents with swelling at mid shaft of femur and low grade fever. ESR is mildly raised. x-ray shows a lamellated periosteal reaction. next line of investigation:
questions.solution:
This is clinical presentation of some chronic or aggressive lesion of femur the probabilities are Ewings Sarcoma or chronic osteomyelitis as both can have same presentation (most common presentation of Ewings is pain, swelling and fever which are same as infection or osteomyelitis) and periostealreaction (Lamellated reaction or Onion peel reaction is seen in both malignant bone tumors like Ewings and Chronic osteomyelitis), thus the next investigation will be MRI to look at the extent of lesion, its soft tissue component .Further we need to obtain the tissue for confirmation of diagnosis (culture for infection and histopathology for tumors)and in this regards MRI can help us localize the margin of lesion for localizing the site of biopsy on the basis of last extent of marrow edema. Biopsy is always taken from the margin of the lesion as the centre of lesion has necrosis and biopsy from the centre will have dead cells only and secondly from margin you can also take normal tissue to compare the affected tissue.

Reference. maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 243
